I'm not a fan of how the opening video in this series claims people only act when they believe the benefits outweigh the cost. I doubt that's true.

There is arguably such a think as akrasia, where we act in such a way that we don't believe the benefits outweigh the cost. I appear to do this every day, which is one reason why I hate myself and feel bad most of the time.

Some people deny the existence of akrasia-- for instance, by claiming we subconsciously believe what we're doing is best, even if we consciously believe what we're doing isn't best. Well, maybe. But that's a highly contentious claim about psychology and subconscious motivations, not an established fact.

Of course, as economists, you can use simplified models that remove akrasia from the equation. That may be totally fine, depending on the nature and purpose of the model. But that doesn't mean akrasia doesn't exist in real life.

TAKE NOTE OF THESE Y'ALL


INTRODUCTION TO ECONOMICS
Economics by Alfred Marsh - study of man in the ordinary business of life. It enquires how he gets his income and how uses it. Thus, it is on the one side, the study of wealth and on the other and more important side, a part of the study of man.
Benefit outweights the cost
Opportunity cost – whatever you give up to do something.
Two most important assumptions in economics
1. People have unlimited wants and limited resources.
Scarcity – The tension between infinite wants and finite resources. – this also means that we must make a choice.
2. Everything has a cost.
if these assumptions are true, we need a way to analyze our choices and get the most from our limited resources.
Economist adjust theories supported by data and understanding of incentives.
Incentives – a set of external (rather than intrinsic) motivators that explain people’s choices.
Macro studies the economics as a whole; it looks at the whole nation’s output, unemployment, interest rates, government.
Macroeconomics answers questions like:
“will unemployment rise if there’s an increase in taxes?”
“will an increase in the money supply boost output, or just increase inflation?”
Macroeconomics – The study of production, employment, prices, & policies on a nationwide scale.
Macroeconomist get more airtime because they predict direction of the overall economy, and work with the media and businesses and congress the Federal Reserve.
Microeconomics answers question like:
“How many workers should we hire to maximize profit?’
“If our competitor releases their product on May, when is the best time to release our product?”
Microeconomics – The study of consumers, workers, and firms interact to generate outcomes in specific markets.
Macro and micro-economist are two different groups asking different questions under one academic umbrella.

Using dollar amounts to analyze comparative military spending is flawed in several ways:
1. Amount spent doesn't gain equal results in each nation. Our greatest rival nation, China is developing and fielding a military that is growing larger and more sophisticated technologically for less money, because it is a totalitarian nation that controls prices.

2. Much of our spending is on benefits for those who serve...China lacks these costs, again because it is a dictatorship.
3. The U.S. spends as much as it does on the military because much of the rest of the world sits back and relies on the U.S. for defense, such as why NATO nations are able to field such small forces and heavily fund social services because we provide most of their defense capabilities.
4. If you examine the total U.S. budget, the military only gets about 17-18% on average. In contrast, social programs get nearly 50%. To see this you must look at the whole budget. Many people look at just discretionary spending which makes the military appear to get a far larger proportion of the budget because the bulk of its funding comes from that portion of the budget. Most spending on social programs is part of the mandatory spending portion of the budget. When combined it is clear we spend way more on social programs than on military.

I'm not surprised but this is a weak representation of economics. Although this is accurate textbook information that is taught in most schools, it is  misleading and not very intelligent. The idea that economics is about the rational decision-making of individuals is a very specific, very flawed, and very new idea within economics. Economics is a social science and moral philosophy with different paradigms. Adam Smith, the father of economics, called it 'political economy'. Good economics should recognize that the real world is messy and complicated. In real life businesses, people, and governments do not use this kind of 'economics' to function and succeed. They succeed because of tactics and behaviors specific to their own areas of expertise and as a result of their interactions with and position within institutions like media, finance, legal systems, politics, culture, etc. If you are looking beyond succeeding in 101 classes (because this video WILL help with that), but what to really understand economics as a social science, start by learning about the history of economic thinkers and schools of thought. "The Worldly Philosophers" by Robert Heilbronner is a good place to start. Then to understand where Economics has shifted to, learn about Ludwig von Mises, F.A. Hayek, Milton Friedman. This stuff is boring to a lot of people but if you wanna understand economics you gotta learn it. I enjoy it.

what is economics?
-"a study of Man(and woman) in the ordinary business of life.
It enquires how he gets his income and how he uses it.
Thus, it is on the one side, the study of wealth and on the other side and more important side, a part of the study of Man(and woman)"
- the study of scarcity and choices.


Opportunity cost: Whatever you give up to do something.
Incentives: A set of external(rather than intrinsic) motivators that explain people's choices.(pervert incentives; rat tails.)

the 2 most important assumptions in economics:
-1.people have unlimited wants but limited resources.
Scarcity: the tension between infinite wants and finite resources.


-2.everything has a cost.




and if these assumptions are true, we need a way to analyze our choices and get the most from our limited resources.=> and that's economics.

Intro to Economics:


-MacroEconomics: the study of production, employment, prices and policies on a nationwide scale.
it answers questions like:
-> will unemployment rise if there's an increase in taxes?
-> will an increase in the money supply boost output, or just increase inflation?
-> will a slump in European economies cause the U.S economy to slow down?

-MicroEconomics: the study of how consumers, workers, and firms interact to generate outcomes in specific markets.
-> how many workers should we hire to maximize profit?
-> if our main competitor releases their product in May, when is the best time to release our product?
-> which is better at fighting climate change, a gas tax or increasing fuel efficiency?

If you want to understand economics, you need to study Psychology. Economics is based on the tenet "with all things being equal". However in essence things are constantly changing.

Dear authors,

With all respect to your knowledge, the range of topic does not need 40 lectures, if we consider for whom these lectures are intended. As a retired teacher of economics, I woul like to call your attention to introducing levels or grading or matching your ideas on economics knoweldge only to the specific needs of people living at different levels.

At a basic level, i.e. buyers and consumers of everyday consumption are concerned mostly with the choice between needs and means, but notions like scarcity and costs but are of no immediate value for them. Just think of barter exchange at low income families. Fro them knowledge of micro or macro economics is of no value.

The next level may involve people responsible for keeping up their family, or their local family business, which is still on the thrershold of the micro -economics, with still less care to least costs and efficiency, because they are also contradicting and have negative effects on quality.

Higher levels may help in gaining insight into micro economics, wtih some aspects to macro-economics, bu t again with keeping with the proverb, less is often more. Many cannot give up a low-paying jobs as those better paid my need giving up your family or even cultural values, etc.

All in all , please slow down and be more careful when offering your wide range of knowledge only to those, who really need it, without raising false expectation in matters that are beyond their control.

Best regards. Pavol Bajusz

I mean... walking isn't the only option. It just seems like it because as Americans we are surrounded by a culture of individualism. There is also the possibility of public transport. If there is a demand, there can be another kind of supply as long as it fills the needs of the people. Community is exactly what we need. People complain that with social media we are getting away from the norms of social interaction. Well, why not approach this problem? We can promote ideals that are important in everything. There is no escaping propaganda in the modern world. We should approach the issue by promoting a culture of intellectualism instead of anti-intellectualism. What is misinformation? How does it work? Well, you see it, so you are likely to remember it and rely on it. People often forget to question where information comes from, and they deem it unnecessary because "I found it" by hearing it professed. There is so much in the world that sounds crazy or hard to believe anyways. That's not good to do though. We should seek truth. We should seek to promote sharing among the communities. This includes the people that we don't like to hear from. Everyone can learn from one another. Isaac Newton couldn't have stood on the shoulders of giants without community. There are other people in the world. We should see to it that the information that gets shared and reproduced is from real experts. Experts can disagree too, but that's not about whether something like evolution is real. They argue about the finer details of things. What gives that person the right to be called an expert? It is related to the years that they put into understanding the topic at hand. It isn't exactly that though. It relates to how well their view stands up when they argue with other experienced individuals on the topic. Hopefully these others have differing views. Can they provide valid reasons for their beliefs? Can their reasons, their premises, be shown to most likely be true given the current standards of the community? There we are. It's all about community. Economics is too. The broad "consumer" is a grouping of all the people who could potentially be a customer. In economics, it is you versus the world. You might as well help it to all work together instead of isolating yourself and pretending other people don't exist. If you want money, you have to deal with other people. Don't want money? Well, I suppose you can become a hermit. That's still possible here in our world for now. Sooner or later though, someone is going to decide that they want that land you are sitting on, or climate change will make it difficult to thrive.

What ever you give up to do something

The study of production, employment, prices, and policies on a national wide scale

Microeconomics:

The study of consumers, workers, firms interact to generate outcomes in the specific markets

Some notes if any one needs them!

-Economics is the study of people and choices
-Important assumptions
-scarcity = tensions between infinite wants but finite resources
-everything has a cost → no such thing as a free lunch
→ thus it is a balance between weighing cost and benefits
-Economists suggest government policies based on incentives (a set of external, as opposed to internal, motivators that explains people’s choices → (ie. govt. Changing school’s incentives from reward per student enrolled, to student graduated)
-need to provide incentive for health industry to produce the best quality for the lowest cost
-macro economics looks at the country’s economy as a whole → unemployment, interest, inflation, spending, growth, etc → answers questions like “will a rise in European trade bring deficit to American Economy?”
-microeconomics answer more specific questions to businesses like employees vs profit, etc

First of all thank you! I'm an economist in academia and I appreciate the accessibility that your videos bring. Being a bit of a nerd I listen to quite a bit of economics. The private sector comment about the computer is grossly inaccurate and misleading. Mariana Mazzacuto in the Entrepreneurial State outlines that almost every disruptive technology comes from public funding or public agencies. These technologies include the internet, GPS, touchscreen (if your using an iPad), microchip, Siri, funding for the Google algorithm, and the satélite. Non computer related public funded tech includes ion-lithium battery (electric car), GPS, over 50% of new molecules used in pharmaceuticals (no me2 drugs), and virtually all vaccines. There is virtually no evidence that the profit motive and competition lead to creativity, and there several studies that conclude the profit motive decreases intrinsic motivation, leads to less collaboration, and narrows focus. The Ted Talks by Daniel Pink on motivation discusses a social experiments carried out by the London School of Economics, US government, and Indian academic institutions all the same experiment which gives a monied incentive in some cases and no financial incentive in others. In all cases in all cultures, the more incentived the worse the outcome. The Harvard Business Review has published extensively about the misnomer of "capitalism leading to your laptop" or creativity. The manufacturing and distribution is a better argument, however the way it is framed and the example chosen being a disruptive technology gives the assumption that the profit motive competition brought us the internet and the computer and that is flat unequivocaly incorrect. https://hbr.org/1998/09/how-to-kill-creativity
https://hbr.org/1993/09/why-incentive-plans-cannot-work
https://hbr.org/2016/10/the-case-against-long-term-incentive-plans
https://hbr.org/2011/11/people-dont-need-a-profit-motive-to-innovate
http://cep.lse.ac.uk/pubs/download/dp1112.pdf
And Dr. Mariana Mazzacuto's The Entrepreneurial State Thank you for what you do, however in your position in education, and reaching such a large audience we need accuracy and nuance. The over simplification offered in this video is dangerously inaccurate
Mazzucato, M. (2015). The entrepreneurial state: debunking public vs. private sector myths. New York: Public Affairs

Just buy Thomas Sowell's Basic Economics. It's better explained and easy to read and it is finite. Here is my major example why:

Marshall's definition of Economics: A study of man in the ordinary business of life. It enquires how he gets his income and how he uses it. Thus, it is on the one side, the study of wealth and on the other and more important side, a part of the study of man.

Sowell's definition of economics (well, how I remember it): The study of the creation and distribution of goods and services to fight scarcity.

Why I prefer the Sowell's definition is because it is finite and encompassing of the subject. Marshall's is good, and historically important for sure; but it isn't as finite as I'd personally like.

Education - Government shouldn't be involved in education in the first place. Leave it entirely to students (and parents) to decide where they want to be educated. Let it be subject to the free market, which produces higher quality at lower prices. Rather than trying to incentives institutions to perform better, they would have incentive through a free market. If they don't perform, people shop elsewhere.

You always get this from the Left. We spend more than the next several countries on military. That's true, but that's not the whole picture. We spend more because we are a larger world power and we are more wealthy than most countries. If you look at it in terms of percentage of spending, we only spend 3-4% of our GDP and military spending only accounts for less than 16% of our total federal spending. Of course, we could still spend less. We can use our military more efficiently and effectively. Higher technological innovation means we are also able to do more with less. However, I would first like to get rid of so many other expenditures that are no legitimate roles of government in the first place. I believe the only legitimate role of government is in protecting the people's rights to their own person and property. You are not allowed to murder, rape, steal, commit fraud, or otherwise infringe on another individual's rights to their own person/property. Government protects against such infringements of our rights through law enforcement, a justice system, and a military. Everything else should be left to the people to decide for themselves. Remove all illegitimate government spending, use the extra tax revenue to pay off the national debt, eliminate all federal taxes, replace them with a single flat consumption tax that would be simple and fair to all (with some exemptions on basic staple food items), and then I'll be happy to also downsize the military. Already, I don't believe we should be in any nation that we are not currently at war with. We spend over $150 billion/year on foreign bases. Removing that already decreases military spending from $598 to $448 billion.

Way to tell it one-sided. There are many opportunity costs around military spending:

- If the military budget were smaller we could give more money to poor people (thus creating more people) or we could just not take it from people in the first place.
- If the US military in particular were not so large, the money would be spent elsewhere as every country under US protection would have to raise their own militaries which would then be used against each other (see all of human history).
- If the US military had not been large, there would not have been a cold war, we would all be speaking Russian.
- If the US military was not large, it could not protect a wealthy country (the US as well as allies) from people coming in and simply taking it with their militaries (again, see all of human history).
- If the US military was not large, it could not protect the Philippines, Japan, Singapore, etc from China)
- If the US military was not large, it would not be able to oppose ISIS (and no one else really is)

The list goes on. Just because you want more money for your socialist agenda (or Tom's) doesn't mean it isn't better spent on a large military.

When they mention "man" in old quotes, they are not talking about male people. The word has no gender. It is just a homonym for the word "man" as in "a man". "Man" in this context means human kind or human race. It does not mean only the male component of the human race. If you say, "man and woman," you are effectively saying, "the human race and woman." 

This is one of my pet peeves. I am a feminist, but I'm not going to mutilate the language over this misunderstanding. I'm sorry. "Man" as in "mankind" comes from the Anglo-Saxon word "mann." It was originally and inherently gender neutral. Another word "wæpenmann" is used to mean a male man in the modern sense.

Liberals ARE pro-business, Conservatives are ANTI-business. Look to the U.K. and how Thatcher came to power. Conservatives hated her for ATTEMPTING a free market as it meant the state (the aristocracy) would loose control over its wealth and assets (British Rail, and various state entities) by privilege, in favour of competition by motive and not guarantee. Conservative meant that the collective wealth of the U.K. and its people should be in the control of the privileged and historically acquainted of the monarchy. Liberal, on the other hand meant that one (like Thatcher - even though she said she was "Conservative") was in support of a free-market where anyone INDIVIDUAL (anti-collective) could control and access wealth through a level-playing-field free of privileged and historic right. In the early United States, a liberal would have been said to want a free-market and individual ownership well a conservative would support the system of lord and tenant, and constitute control over the ownership and means of production. Also, look at the base definitions of each word. To be liberal means to - put simply - be tolerant of others and thus are willing to partake in economic activity with them (such as corporation or trade). To be CONSERVative, is to generally be protectionist of that in which has value. Thus a Conservative is less likely to partake in an economic activity (or risk - hence a Conservative portfolio v. High-risk portfolio) or cooperative activity such as a business. Once more, look back to the uses of the words "conservative" and "liberal". One will find that before WWII and back before the 1800's mainly, conservative and liberal were opposite as to the common reversal we most often hear today. Finally, as one looks into economic history, the state was often the Conservative entity, well the Liberal was the businessman (once more, just like in the U.K.).

I really, really, really hope that they avoid a heavy American-centric, or Chicago-school, neo-liberal based outlook, and (attempt) to examine this subject (as best as anyone could be expected to) from more unbiased perspective, utilising data showing how economics operates in human societies in reality. In fact, it would be great if they did this instead of adopting an ideological economic theory or perspective: libertarian, neo-liberal, communist, free market or otherwise.  Surely a far better basis for economics the world over is to base economics on the best quality evidence available as to how humans and societies act in reality rather than following some antiquated economic ideology or dogma, before promptly yelling "fascist republican" or "commie liberal" at each other ..?

For a start, I hope they debunk the myth surrounding the concept of opportunity cost as they seem to construct the term here 3:39.
"Opportunity Cost - if you are still watching this video, it means you believe it is the best us of your time or you wouldn't be watching it."
Do people really act in a way that they feel is the best use of their time? The data that has emerged since the era of Reganomics would suggest we pay attention to a whole host of irrational factors in making such "decisions".  Is that a sound basis to declare that I made a "decision" to watch this video based upon what I felt was the best use of my time? I am not sure the evidence supports that view of economics.

On a similar note, should this video not be revised with acknowledgement to the third most important assumption of "modern" economics (4:24): that people are rational actors? I see little to no evidence showing me that they necessarily are, especially in the face of complex or unexpected circumstances.  

The problem with such theories, concepts and assumptions is just that - they are theories, concepts and assumptions.  Without data or evidence to act as a basis, such theories, concepts or assumptions are not simply "flawed" but fundamentally, and often irrevocably flawed.  We risk making evidence to fit economic policy, rather than fitting economic policy to evidence.

Of course, at this moment in time it would be unfair and premature to make any assumption over what exactly will be covered over during this CrashCourse, let alone how it will be covered. Personally I am eagerly looking forward to a thrill-packed 40+(?) weeks (then again, I'm a bit of a nerd, but damn it if I am not proud of it). Still, without data or evidence to provide a basis or platform from which to examine such theories, concepts or assumptions, the temptation for me as a viewer will be, if not to mistrust such suppositions, then to assume the view of Hume and say " to the flames" (or at least, head back to the CrashCourse drawing board).

Hey I'm very happy you are doing an economics Crash course because I love crash course.  I am somewhat worried that about the tone of the first episode.  One of the strange things about economics education is that it has this moral assumption that people make directed choices, and in making this argument it tries to convince me that what choice i made is this oddly more directed choice than it really is.  I put on crash course while i'm doing some mindless physical work because i find it is stimulating enough or i'm just lazy and i don't want to focus on trying to find something new.  Although you can put my choices into the logical rubric of classical economics, some of the most interesting economics I've read about elsewhere tries to take my numerous lazy decisions at face value and analyses why they are made and what it does to a body of economic logic so rigidly tied to rationality.  One thing i really enjoyed about John Green's perspective is his welcoming of the type of mundane perspective that people hold, and an appreciation that it exists.  The fact that my desire to watch this video came from a split second decision of curiosity when prompted by my youtube front-page, is a fascinating and often unexplored expression of economics and human behaviour, but it doesn't look like the rational decision laid out in the video where I consciously weigh the pros and cons of cat videos or skateboarders falling down.  This is important, and its fascinating too.

I'm really excited about Crash Course covering this important topic. 

However, the intro seemed to imply that economics is the science of human choice. That is not correct. Psychology is the science of human choice (and behavior and mental processes etc.)

Economics is the science of efficiency. To be able to predict how societies behave, economics makes very abstract assumptions about humans. On a micro level economics can thus only show how people should behave if we want (pareto-)efficiency and what the outcomes would be if people behaved rationally.

I can only hope that at least one episode will cover behavioral economics and the psychology behind it. It is quite easy to demonstrate that humans are anything but rational. They are, as Dan Ariely puts it, "predictably irrational". Summarizing at least the thinking of Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman would do the topic greater justice and helps not to fall into the trap of "rationalism".

After all, the assumption of perfectly rational actors if often used to blame people themselves for bad economic outcomes even though structural and psychological factors are responsible, not intentional choices.

By looking at many of the comments here, it's clear that crash course economics is desperately needed. Whether you criticise or praise that they are talking about "free market economy" "capitalism" etc., and not talking about "plan economy" "socialism" etc., shows that you probably should follow this show and take notes.

This is economic theory, and as you (should) know, theory is a (abstract) reflection of reality, not the other way around (this is why CC philosophy is desperately needed as well). "Free market" and "plan economy" are non-existent extremes of the economy spectrum. You can't talk about either without talking about other. You may feel that they left out "plan economy"/"socialism", in favour of the other. However, there are no place in the world were it's one or the other, so they're simply talking about "economy". It may seem more free market friendly, since that's what most economies lean towards. I live in the most socialist country of them all (Norway) and I can tell you, it is way more free market than you'd think. You also have to talk about free market mechanisms first to even be able to comprehend plan economy. So before you start laying down your judgement, watch a couple of episodes first.

If you're still in doubt try mentioning one place in the world where there is pure free market or pure plan economy. As soon as someone sell something without notifying the state, it's not pure plan economy, and soon as the government raises their voice about the economy it is not pure free market.

second, resources are not necessarily unlimited (except time, until time travel is invented). this one has a tenuous relation with another econ term: free goods. technically, sunlight isn't unlimited (the sun will fizzle out in a few billion years) but within the human lifespan, it is conceptually unlimited. when nanotech gets really insane, many things we consider scarce today would no longer be so. in the end, the only "limit" to resource is really entropy in the physical sense.

third, opportunity cost is sometimes purely conceptual. if all you really wanted to do was sleep for the next 8 hours, and you actually do sleep the next 8 hours, you really didn't lose out on some other alternative. of course, conceptually, you could've done something else during the 8 hours... but if you don't actually want to, then it becomes a moot point.

Obviously we appreciate this series. The problem is that something like macroeconomics is more of a pseudo science than a science. None of the basic assumptions and predictions have ever been tested. When was a recession ever predicted. Note that chemistry, a science, has such things as repeatability and prediction built in. Its predecessor, alchemy, had neither. Writing down some wild assumptions and solving some differential equations can be fun, but unless the predictions are tested its still just numerology.

For example, the speed of light in a vacuum is a constant. There are no known exceptions.

But consider someone caring for their sick and dying child, or elderly parent. Why do we do it? According to opportunity cost, we should be doing something else, working on another degree to boost earnings or perhaps invest the money in the stock market.
This is only one example, but if this is one end of the spectrum where opportunity cost does not apply, where exactly do we draw the line? Where the pseudoscience macro econ people tell us? (And no we do not care for children because they might be farm hands or care for us when we are older. Neither applies now.)

The real parodox is that physicists working on string theory are the first to admit that their specialty is wild speculation and that they pursue that line of thinking because the math works out. But economists are the last to admit how wildly speculative each and every one of their closely held beliefs are, because they can neither test nor disprove any of it.

Bottom line, macro econ might lead to riches in the short term and disaster in the long term. In other words, a modest proposal.

The problem with a lot of these Crash Course series is not that they are hosted by people other than the Green brothers, though that undoubtedly contributes to the problem.  The problem has to do with tone.  In Crash Courses World and American History, Literature, Biology, Chemistry, etc, the quality that makes these engaging is the fact that they are presented as if the audience were equals who want to find out about a subject that the host knows about.  In series like this as well as US Government and Politics the host treats the audience as if we are infants who need the keychain dangled in front of our collective faces in order to continue paying attention.

Making educational entertainment is an art and if it were as simple as checking off qualities a, b, and c then everything would be equally great.  Sadly, or luckily depending on your perspective, there is no such magic formula.  So there's no reason why the Muppets couldn't, at some point, contribute to making this series both entertaining and educational, but the way this started off was patronizing at best.  The assumption is that economics is such a boring matter that we couldn't possibly devote any brain space to it, so you over compensated right off the bat, which implicitly tells the audience you don't see them as equals who could join you on a discovery.

Bill Nye's show had plenty of wackiness to it, so there's nothing to say you couldn't strike a balance with these things, but his shows were also geared toward a much younger audience than I assumed the Crash Course audience is.  I could be wrong, but seeing as much of the audience came from the Green fan base it would have to include many young adults and you're going to lose them if your schtick is to make this a program fit for an elementary school student's sense of humor with a middle school-high school level material.

Certainly, Liberalism and Conservativism do need to be explored and I understand both of these systems have theories that overlap or have been attempted to be incorporated into a Socialist discourse, but since many Capitalist states continue to explicitly recognize Socialist economic goals in their constitutions and party systems (especially contemporary India and Portugal, and Mexico for most of the last century), wouldn't it make sense to acknowledge this as the third most basic approach to Capitalist economy*?


Even if these countries' ability to uphold Socialist ideals is questionable, just as many countries' adherence to Liberal and Conservative ideals have also been questioned, it seems unfitting to sort the economic theories and history of parties and countries like post-war Italy, the Indian National Congress, and Pan-Africanism as merely liberal in the modern sense of the word.

*I specify "Capitalist", and not a market or planned style economy since Conservativism and Liberalism aren't inherently opposed to economic planning.

Just a few things I would like to address:

1.) For the people complaining about their inclusion of the word "woman" while quoting the economist, saying that they're trying to make a point of sexism without there being any, I think it's important to acknowledge that those arguing that "man" refers to all people seem to be mainly men. It may SEEM like the two in the video are trying to make a point, but as a woman, it's astonishing when you realize just how pervasive such terms in history have (mostly unknowingly) shaped the world view of those who use the language. Terms like "history," "mankind," and "man" were part of my vocabulary to address all people before I ever stopped to notice their wide-reaching and alienating effects. As a woman, even I am surprised by how strange it is to hear "she" being used as a pronoun to represent all people, yet "he" sounds normal. This is not a natural result of biology but a nuanced result of millennia of male-centric texts which reflect the biases of their time. I still think it would have been more useful to change "man" to "people" to avoid this whole debate, but please try to empathize with the need for inclusion of women in discussion of all people. It's not that difficult.

2.) Any person who lives in a capitalist society and spends their money on goods generated by such a society is in fact supporting capitalism, however much you would like to admit it or not. The fact of the matter is even though you may not agree with it (and I definitely can't say capitalism in its current state is ideal) every dollar you give to companies who hold it as their model is exactly the reason they can remain profitable. Most of the time, the aggressive tactics used by such companies do not allow for any other option, and I'm sure this is something they will address in the future, so try not to be too hasty.

Please say the rest of this series isn't going to be this patronising. I love economics, I love crash course and I really do try to give things a good chance before I switch off but I just couldn't make it past the section on opportunity cost without thinking that maybe this wasn't a great use of my time.

I have no desire to be mean or unkind and I have no doubt the presenters, script writers, editors, director and everyone else are brilliant people who work increadibly hard but this is just a huge shift in tone from the other crash course series. One of the assets of crash course is that it could be light hearted with great content without the usual talking down to the audience that you see in school/educational videos. Please don't lose that.

And thank you for all your hard work.
